fields.value: Adult Oral Health in New Zealand, 1976: Kelly Extract

authorAffiliation.value: New Zealand Medical Research Council, Dental Research Unit

dsDescriptionValue.value:
This is an extract from a larger survey.  The extract was created by Jonathan Kelly.  The codebook is for the larger study and is missing sections, however the extract file is defined for each of the variables included.

This study description was access from http://www.nzssds.org.nz/aohnz-metadata

The objectives of the study were:
(1) to determine the standard of oral health, the prevalence of specific oral disease, the results of past dental treatment, and the oral hygiene status of the New Zealand population aged 15 years and over;
(2) to determine oral treatment needs;
(3) to determine public and professional attitudes and behavioural patterns related to dentistry and oral health, with particular reference to the lifetime preservation of natural teeth.
Two surveys were conducted: one of the general public and one of dental practitioners.
 
Variables included in the general population survey were: beliefs about the onset of dental problems, the social stigma attached to various oral conditions and attitudes to use of dental services; beliefs about dentures, dentists’ subsidisation of treatment costs, fluoridation and diet; aspects of personal care, diet and perception of present oral condition; history of contact with the dental system, perceived barriers to use of services and influence of lay or non-professional advisers; details of use of dental services; and advice offered by dentist on oral hygiene and topics of discussion when visiting the dentist.
 
Background variables were respondent’s age, sex, marital status, age and sex of all household members, respondent's ethnic group, skin colour, educational level, occupation, employment status and income. Information was also collected on household composition, household income, spouse’s occupation, and occupation of spouse’s father and of respondent’s father.
 
The dental practitioner survey collected information on: type of practitioner (self-assessment) and extent of special interests; time spent in practice; involvement in continuing education; contact with colleagues; general advice offered by the dentist on the dentist-patient relationship; time spent on different treatment tasks; and attitudes towards the cost of dentistry, prevalence of gingivitis, retention of teeth, auxiliaries, and the undergraduate curriculum.
 
Background characteristics of dentists included age, sex, time in practice and in current practice, and income. Characteristics of practices included type of practice, professional personnel in practice, patient numbers, and source.

value: Territorial Local Authorities in New Zealand as at 23 March 1971 were sorted into two strata: urban and rural. Department of Statistics urban areas, boroughs and other urban groupings with a population of 2,000 persons or over at the 1971 Census of Population and Dwellings were placed in the urban stratum. Remaining areas were placed in the rural stratum.

eneral population survey: adults 15 years and over living in permanent private homes on the North and South Islands of New Zealand
Dental practitioner survey: dental practitioners in New Zealand

fields.value:
The estimated sample size for the survey for each age-sex specific group was 72. With 16 age-sex groups, the sample size was thus to be 1,152. However, this calculation was based on a simple, single-stage random selection, while the sample design proposed for the survey involved a multi-stage systematic cluster sample, which would increase estimation variance and thus increase the required sample size by a factor of 3, to 3,456.
 
The strata were defined as outlined above, and then the size of each was estimated in terms of population aged 15 or over, using Department of Statistics data.
 
The Territorial Local Authorities (TLAs) were ordered geographically, north to south, within each stratum, and a cumulative measure of size table was produced. Then 68 TLAs were selected by systematic random sampling with probability of selection proportional to the size measure. The number of urban and rural primary sampling units (PSUs) selected reflected the relative sizes of the strata.
 
Secondary sampling units (SSUs) were individual census meshblocks or amalgamations of adjacent meshblocks so that the minimum eligible population in any SSU was 50.
Within each selected PSU, 2 SSUs were selected by systematic random sampling with probability proportional to size – thus 136 SSUs were selected.
 
Appropriate sampling fractions were calculated for each SSU so that all adults had an equal probability of selection. Interviewers were given maps with clearly defined start points. They visited each address, recorded the number of eligible inhabitants, and selected eligibles to be surveyed, independent of dwelling, based on the sequence of codes generated for the SSU. So 2 or 3 people might have been surveyed in a large household, and 1 or even none in a small one.

The household survey is conducted in face-to-face interviews with a household reference person or the spouse. All household members age 15 years and older are included in the individual survey. Most individual interviews are carried out face-to-face, but a small portion were interviewed by leaving and retrieving the questionnaire, or by telephone.
